heading: 1 Study Premise
text: Body Advocacy Movement Study (Phase 1: 2021-2023) pilot study investigating feasibility, acceptability, preliminary efficacy eating disorder risk reduction intervention developed EMBARK lab 2020.existing, dissonance programs (.e. Body Project) target reductions thin-ideal internalization, fears related fatness weight gain may particularly salient cognitive target among current past eating disorder symptomatology (Levinson et al., 2014). effort mitigate risk ED onset relapse among high-risk young adults (.e. ED partial- full-remission /ongoing subthreshold ED symptoms), current project includes development initial evaluation novel, peer-led intervention focuses specifically fear fatness anti-fat bias (Body Advocacy Movement; BAM).project aims recruit 60 young adults (ages 18-26) – randomized standard dissonance intervention program (Body Project; N = 20) BAM (N = 40). objective examine degree BAM can reduce fear fatness weight gain along internalized anti-fat bias reduce risk ED symptom exacerbation promote ongoing ED recovery high-risk, young adult sample. evaluate feasibility acceptability BAM estimate effects intervention self-report behavioral measures fear weight gain fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. conduct initial effect size comparisons Body Project determine whether BAM shows potency specifically targeting fear fatness anti-fat bias.

heading: 1.1 Specific Aims
text: Aim 1: Examine acceptability feasibility BAM high-risk young adult sample. Acceptability: Acceptability assessed via attrition across 4-session intervention along qualitative feedback brief survey post-intervention. expect meet benchmarks high acceptability (average ratings > 4 [5] post-intervention survey; < 20% attrition). Feasibility: Feasibility benchmarked via intervention adherence (average competency > 8.0 0-10 scale) recruitment goals.Aim 2: Estimate effects intervention fear fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. hypothesize BAM intervention result acute reductions (post-intervention) fatphobia anti-fat bias across self—report behavioral measures, outperforming Body Project targets related anti-fat bias, specifically.

heading: 2 Procedures
text: first wave study include recruitment 60 young adults (ages 18-26) take part intervention improve body image advocate body positivity. Participants randomized Body Project (n = 20) BAM (n = 40). Participants groups complete two peer-led, 2-hour sessions, complete series assessments baseline, post-intervention, 1-month 6-month follow-.

heading: 2.1 Recruitment
text: Recruitment sources include: (1) University Health Services UW-Madison area colleges universities (2) flyers area businesses (e.g. fitness centers, coffee shops) (3) online advertisement social media platforms (4) direct, peer--peer recruitment peer facilitators, (5) campus e-mail recruitment.

heading: 3.1 The Body Project
text: use 2-session, peer-facilitated dissonance-based Body Project Intervention, asks participants engage series exercises critique culturally-sanctioned appearance ideals, specifically targets reductions thin-ideal internalization (Becker et al., 2006).

heading: 3.2 The Body Advocacy Movement
text: BAM leverages dissonance exposure-based intervention strategies, adapting common exercises used promote body acceptance challenge sociocultural body ideals specifically target anti-fat bias internalized fatphobia. Participants BAM (1) Define anti-fat bias fatphobia explore constructs manifest personal beliefs interpersonal interactions, (2) Engage imaginal exposure exercises challenge fears related fatness weight gain (3) Reflect fears fatness align personal values, (4) Learn new ways challenge fear fatness internalized anti-fat bias (5) Discuss ways challenge anti-fat bias institutional societal level. Intervention content.

heading: 3.2.1 Session 1
text: Session 1 includes introductions, discussing identities clarifying terminology, exercise defining anti-fat bias fatphobia. Participants asked complete imaginal exposure exercise several times week write recount ‘worst-case scenario’ might fear happen gained significant amount weight.

heading: 3.2.2 Session 2
text: Session 2 includes debriefing exposure homework identification ways one might uproot internalized fear fatness, along series role plays peer facilitators play role friend family member situation evokes anti-fat attitudes, participants practice challenging attitudes. Participants also identify ways challenge anti-fat bias society commit engaging one activity coming week. exit exercise, write ‘response letter’ worst-case scenario.

heading: 3.3 Peer Facilitators
text: employ peer-facilitated model group intervention program, small group 6-10 facilitators undergo 8-hour training program, similar Stice et al. (2017). Peer facilitators train teams – peer-leader team role-play delivery entire intervention observed peer leaders teams , receiving live clinical supervision.

heading: 3.4 Intervention Fidelity
text: Sessions audio recorded reviewed two members research staff. Audio recorded sessions rated fidelity competence. Research staff independently code randomly selected sample 50% sessions implementation fidelity facilitator competence using checklists assessing major exercises discussion topics session. component rated degree accurate presentation (10-point scale “adherence; section skipped” “Perfect; material section presented written”). Facilitator competence rated using 12 items assessing indicators competence (e.g., leaders express ideas clearly appropriate pace, leaders attempt allot equal speaking time members) 10-point scale.

heading: 5.1 Childhood Trauma Questionnaire
text: Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ) standardized self-report inventory measures severity childhood trauma participants’ tendency underreport maltreatment, validated clinical non-clinical populations (Bernstein et al., 1997; Villano et al., 2004). CTQ retrospective 28-item self-report inventory measures severity different types childhood trauma, producing five clinical subscales comprised five items: Emotional Abuse, Physical Abuse, Sexual Abuse, Emotional Neglect, Physical Neglect. measure also includes three-item Minimization/Denial scale indicating potential underreporting maltreatment. Participants respond item context “growing ” answer according five-point Likert scale ranging “never” = 1 “often” = 5, producing scores 5 25 trauma subscale. three items comprising Minimization/Denial scale dichotomized (“never” = 0, responses = 1) summed; total one (1) greater suggests possible underreporting maltreatment (false negatives).ScoringScoring CTQ includes:Renaming variables descriptive namesRenaming variables descriptive namesCreating sum scores subscale (5 items 5 subscales)Creating sum scores subscale (5 items 5 subscales)Dichotomizing items minimization scaleDichotomizing items minimization scaleSumming dichotimized items create minimization scoreSumming dichotimized items create minimization scoreKey VariablesAll variables appendix _25 reflect final scoring weighted subscale sum scores < 25% missing data.ctq_emo_abuse_25ctq_phys_abuse_25ctq_sex_abuse_25ctq_emo_neglect_25ctq_phys_neglect_25ctq_minimize_complete (CTQ minimization score - completers )

heading: 5.3 Dieting and Weight History Questionnaire (DWHQ)
text: Dieting Weight History Questionnaire (DWHQ), developed Witt et al. (2013) measure three dimensions dieting: (1) frequency past dieting overeating (.e. history dieting), (2) current dieting lose weight, (3) weight suppression, difference individual’s current weight highest previous weight.ScoringKey Variables

heading: 5.6 Eating Disorder Fear Questionnaire (EDFQ)
text: EDFQ self-report measure eating disorder specific fears, developed validated undergraduate college students along clinical sample eating disorder patients Levinson et al. (2019). five-factor strucutre EDFQ established, consisting subscales assessing fear weight gain, social consequences, personal consequences, physical sensations, social eating. EDFQ demonstrates good internal consistency convergent, divergent, incremental, construct validity.ScoringKey Variables

heading: 5.9 USDA Adult Food Security Survey Module (FSSM)
text:
U.S. Adult Food Security - Survey Module (FSSM) (Carlson et al., 1999) developed USDA Food Nutrition Services 1995 assessing food security within households, specifically use Current Population Survey. FSSM primarily designed unidimensional, 10-item scale. Previous use college students indicates students respond differently FSSM items relative general population, FSSM may less reliable measure food insecurity college students relative adults US population (Nikolaus et al., 2019), potential misclassification FI college students (Nikolaus et al., 2020), note caution interpreting findings measure young adult sample. however, present, alternative measure FI amongst college students robust track-record validity.Responses “yes,” “often,” “sometimes,” “almost every month,” “months every month” coded affirmative. sum affirmative responses 10 questions Adult Food Security Scale raw score scale.Food security status assigned follows:
|
| - Raw score 0: High food security
| - Raw score 1-2: Marginal food security
| - Raw score 3-5: Low food security
| - Raw score 6-10: low food security
|
|dichotomizing, food security status first two categories combination described food secure latter two food insecure.ScoringData cleaning includes:1-2. heading: 5.10 Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7)
text:
Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7) (Spitzer et al., 2006) seven-item instrument used measure assess severity generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). item asks individual rate severity symptoms past two weeks. Response options include “”, “several days”, “half days” “nearly every day”. GAD-7 widely-used well-validated measure anxiety screening (Sapra et al., 2020). GAD-7 scored unidimensional scale summing 7 items, cutoffs can also employed interpretation clinical severity:
|
| Minimal anxiety = 0-4
| Mild Anxiety = 5-9
| Moderate Anxiety = 10-14
| Severe Anxiety = 15-21.
|
| score 10 points higher indicates probably anxiety disorder, 89% sensitivity 82% specificity GAD.ScoresheetData Cleaning includes:1-2 Selecting variables relevant current measure recoding raw variables make consistent way scoring: = 0, several days =1, half days = 2, nearly every day =33-5 creation additional variable based sum scores reflecting participant’s anxiety levels6 creating dichotomized measure likely anxiety (cutoff score 10 greater), along clinical severity index (minimal, mild, moderate, severe)Key variablesgad_sum_25 (Sum GAD-7, 25% less items missing weighted N items completed)gad_cutoffs (GAD-7 anxiety severity cutoffs employed)gad_anx_disorder (GAD-7 probable anxiety disorder Yes/)

heading: 5.11 Goldfarb Fear of Fat Scale
text: Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale (GFFS) 10-item scale introduced 1985 diagnostic tool measure one’s fear fat can indicator development eating disorder (Goldfarb et al., 1985). used screening tool clinical non-clinical groups, GFFS strong test-retest reliability psychometric properties (Przybyta-Basista et al., 2022). addition, test also shown high validity populations without eating disorders (Goldfarb, 2010) original factor structure defined single-factor, Przybyta-Basista et al. (2022) also supported two-factor structure non-clinical sample: (1) fear weight gain (2) fear losing control eating/weight. GFFS uses 4-point scale 1 equal untrue 4 equal trueScoringData Cleaning includes:1-2. Select rename variables; recode labels scale begin 0 instead 1 untrue equal 0 true equal 3.3-4. Sum total scores create variable reflect completing > 75% items. Also create two subscales (FOWG Fear LOC) alternative scoring.|Scoring Note GFFS scoring procedure re-scales item scores 0-3 instead 1-4, meaning sum scores scaled 0-21 instead 7-28. compare means studies using GFFS, add 7 sum score.Key VariablesFor variables , _25 appendix reflects individuals <25% missing items scale included weighted sums based number items completedgffs_sum_25 (sum items)gffs_fowg_25 (sum fear weight gain subscale)gffs_loc_25 (sum loss control items)

heading: 5.12 Ideal Body Stereotype Scale - Revised (IBSS-R)
text: Ideal Body Stereotype Scale - Revised (IBSS-R), brief (6-item), unidimensional scale designed measure internalization ideal-body stereotype (specifically women), developed Stice et al. (1996). IBSS-R utilized measure thin-ideal internalization eating disorder prevention research (Stice et al., 2019), making suitable benchmark measure existing effect sizes.ScoringScoring includes:1. Selecting renaming variables.2. Creating mean score 6 IBSS itemsKey Variablesibss_mean_25 (Mean IBSS items, 25% less missing)

heading: 5.13 Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS)
text:
Positive Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) js 20-item, 2 dimensional measure introduced 1988 measure one’s positive negative moods (Watson et al., 1988). Compared scales measuring positive negative affect, PANAS high internal consistency validity. addition, scale also shows consistent reliability, even measured across gender (Crawford & Henry, 2004). PANAS asks respondents indicate felt previous week using 5-point likert scale 1 = slightly 5 = extremely. two dimensions include 10-item positive affect subscale 10-item negative affect subscaleScoringData cleaning includes:1. Selecting renaming variables2. Computing subscale sum scores:  - Sum total scores questions 1, 3, 5, 8, 9, 11, 13, 15, 16, 18 panas_positive_sum
  - Sum total scores questions 2, 4, 6, 7, 10, 12, 14, 17, 19 panas_negative_sumKey VariablesSum scores reflect weighted sums 25% less missing data:panas_positive_sum_25 (sum scores questions identifying positive affect course last week)panas_negative_sum_25 (sum scores questions identifying negative affect course last week)

heading: 5.15 Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire (SATAQ)
text:
Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire-4 (SATAQ) designed assess societal interpersonal aspects appearance ideals. SATAQ five validated factors: Internalization Thin/Low Body Fat, Internalization Muscular/Athletic, Pressures Family, Pressures Media, Pressures Peers. scale structure confirmed 3 independent geographically diverse samples women United States (East Coast N = 440, West Coast N = 304, North/Midwest N = 349). SATAQ-4 scale scores demonstrated excellent reliability good convergent validity measures body image, eating disturbance, self-esteem. measure also validated college males United States (N = 271); however, evidence underlying structure unique men. purposes current data, 5-factor structure employed scoring.ScoresheetCleaning Steps include:1-3. heading: 5.17 Universal Measure of Bias - Fat (UMB-fat)

heading: 6.1 Weight Implicit Association Test (Weight IAT)
text: Weight-IAT task data housed (long-format) data set within study database, keys subject_id timepoint.Weight-IAT validated measure automatic, unconscious attitudes previously used evaluate implicit weight-related biases (Phelan et al., 2014) Weight-IAT compares accuracy , time required categorize images larger-bodied thinner people together positively- negatively-valanced words. Outcomes include reaction time percentage correct categorizations.

heading: 6.1.1 Scoring
text:
IAT scoring algorithm involves several steps, rigorous scoring procedure involving 12 specifications (Greenwald et al., 2003)Steps include:Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Eliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msEliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msUse remaining trialsUse remaining trialsNo extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)Compute mean correct latencies blockCompute mean correct latencies blockCompute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Compute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Replace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msReplace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msNo transformationNo transformationAverage resulting values four blocksAverage resulting values four blocksCompute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Compute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Average two quotients Step 11Average two quotients Step 11R code used cleaning Weight-IAT data prior implementing scoring algorithm available - yet available.
R code completing scoring algorithm cleaned data available - yet avaialble

heading: 6.2 Weight Based Approach Avoidance Task (Weight-AAT)
text: interactive task manipulate congruency reward- threat-related outcomes – task derived Weaver et al. (2020). Participants learn, trial--error, three responses, indicated geometric shapes, select achieve particular outcome. Critically, response option associated probability reward outcome (points) additional outcome (.e., images body parts larger bodies). response-outcome contingencies (e.g., option likely lead reward) switch throughout task, half time option likely lead reward also likely lead seeing large body images (Conflict Phase), half time highest reward option least likely lead seeing large body images (Congruent Phase) . Participants instructed earn many points possible (reward goals), allowing us test biases decision-making large body images likely. trial, participants choose shape, , delay (.5-.75s), point outcome trial appeared image (presented 1.5–2.5s) image remained screen, indicating positive negative value (e.g., +5 -7). Trials separated fixation cross, presented .5-1.5s. type image (trauma-related neutral) direction points (positive, negative) experimentally manipulated reflect probabilities aligned type phase. number points won/lost randomly generated (range: 1-10). Task Phases counterbalanced order allow initial task structure learning introduction Conflict Phase.trials, outcomes (image type, point win/loss) either 80%, 50%, 20% chance occurring. image type point win/loss probabilities independent one another. Probabilities outcome left right shape (circle hexagon) adjusted throughout task create Conflict Congruent Phases.

Code scoring Weight-AAT using Linear mixed Effects Model Approach available - yet availableWeight-AAT task data housed (long-format) data set within study database, keys subject_id timepoint.Linear Mixed Effects Model uses trial-wise outcomes (.e. modeling outcomes trials participant). Prior analysis, predictors outcomes scaled analysis including block, Phase (Conflict = -1, Congruent - 1), Trial (z-scored within block) regressed Total Points (scaled 0 1). Trial coded account learning within block (e.g. trial number 1-25 z-scored represent linear learning throughout trial).Ultimate outputs model include random intercept random slope Phase, Block, Trial, interactions account individual variability – e.g:

heading: 7 Sample Description
text:
2021, ran pilot version program (N = 29) randomizing young adults either 2-session Body Project Body Advocacy Movement (BAM; described ) intervention (see Figure 1 Pilot enrollment). Average fear fatness full sample baseline similar samples ‘repeat dieters’ (Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale average Baseline = 23.26), lower clinical samples active EDs. subsample second wave recruitment completed measure ED history, questions specifically assessing ED diagnostic criteria.
